testCases.name: test_case_56

Seafloor spreading is responsible for the creation of new oceanic crust and the widening of ocean basins.
testCases.expectedOutput: It is assumed that the mid-ocean ridge is the place where the sea floor splits due to the rise of heat flow, and molten magma ejects from it to push the rocks on both sides to form a new sea floor. The rising mantle material condenses to form a new ocean crust, and pushes the first formed ocean floor to gradually expand symmetrically to both sides. The expansion of the seafloor at the mid-ocean ridge may cause the continents on both sides of the new ocean to gradually move away from each other, and may also cause the old oceanic crust to subduct and submerge along the Benioff zone (subduction zone) at the trench of the continental margin, and return to the mantle, thus completing the renewal of the old oceanic crust.

testCases.name: test_case_41
testCases.actualOutput: Physical weathering and chemical weathering are two types of weathering processes that break down rocks and minerals. Physical weathering, also known as mechanical weathering, involves the physical breakdown of rocks and minerals into smaller pieces without changing their chemical composition. This can occur through processes such as freeze-thaw cycles, abrasion, and pressure release. Chemical weathering, on the other hand, involves the chemical alteration of rocks and minerals through reactions with water, air, and other chemicals. This can result in the formation of new minerals and the dissolution of others. Both physical and chemical weathering play important roles in shaping the Earth's surface and creating soil.
testCases.expectedOutput: The rock is only formed by mechanical crushing, and its chemical composition has not changed, which is physical weathering. Chemical weathering refers to the weathering process of chemical decomposition of rocks under the action of oxygen, water and various acids and organisms dissolved in water.

The rising mantle material condenses to form a new ocean crust, and pushes the first formed ocean floor to gradually expand symmetrically to both sides; The expansion of the seafloor at the mid-ocean ridge may cause the continents on both sides of the new ocean to gradually move away from each other, and may also cause the old oceanic crust to subduct and submerge along the Benioff zone (subduction zone) at the trench of the continental margin, and return to the mantle, thus completing the renewal of the old oceanic crust;

testCases.name: test_case_126
testCases.actualOutput: Yu is a geoscience concept that refers to the amount of water that is stored in the soil and is available for plant uptake. It is typically measured in millimeters and is calculated as the difference between the field capacity and the permanent wilting point of the soil. The field capacity is the amount of water that the soil can hold after excess water has drained away, while the permanent wilting point is the amount of water that the soil can hold before plants begin to wilt and die. Yu is an important concept in agriculture and hydrology, as it helps to determine the amount of water that is available for plant growth and the amount of water that needs to be added to the soil through irrigation.
testCases.expectedOutput: The largest chronostratigraphic unit, corresponding to the time "universe", is divided according to the largest stage of biological evolution, that is, the existence and mode of living matter.

testCases.name: test_case_127
testCases.actualOutput: In geoscience, circles refer to the geometric shapes that are formed by the intersection of a plane and a sphere. These circles can be classified into three types: great circles, small circles, and parallel circles. Great circles are the largest circles that can be drawn on a sphere and have the same diameter as the sphere itself. Small circles are any circles that are smaller than a great circle and have a smaller diameter than the sphere. Parallel circles are circles that are parallel to each other and have the same diameter.

testCases.name: test_case_133
testCases.actualOutput: Extended zone is a region of the Earth's crust that is undergoing extensional tectonics, which is the stretching and thinning of the crust. This can occur due to the movement of tectonic plates, such as when two plates are moving away from each other. Extended zones are characterized by the presence of normal faults, which are fractures in the crust where one block of rock has moved downward relative to the other block. These zones can also be associated with the formation of rift valleys, which are elongated depressions in the Earth's surface that are created by the stretching and thinning of the crust.

As the ocean basin widens, it eventually reaches a maximum size, after which it begins to close as the oceanic crust is subducted beneath the continental crust. This leads to the formation of a mountain range and the eventual collision of the two continents. The cycle then repeats itself, with the formation of a new ocean basin and the opening of a new rift. testCases.name: test_case_153
testCases.actualOutput: The Fuping Movement is a geological event that occurred during the Late Cretaceous period, approximately 70 million years ago. It was a significant tectonic event that resulted in the formation of the Fuping Basin in northern China. The movement involved the collision of the North China Block and the Yangtze Block, which caused the uplift and deformation of the Fuping Basin. The movement also resulted in the formation of the Fuping Fault, which is a major fault line that runs through the basin. The Fuping Movement is an important event in the geological history of China, as it played a significant role in the formation of the region's landscape and geological features.
testCases.expectedOutput: It refers to the tectonic movement that occurred in North China at the end of the Archean (2.6-25 billion years), accompanied by a large number of magmatic activities and metamorphism, and strong folding and denudation of the crust. This movement solidified the Archean active sediments in the area, increased the siliceous and aluminous crust, and formed the ancient land core of North China.

testCases.name: test_case_167
testCases.actualOutput: The Hercynian movement is a geological event that occurred during the Paleozoic era, approximately 300 to 250 million years ago. It was a period of intense mountain building and deformation, resulting in the formation of the Hercynian orogeny, which is now known as the Variscan orogeny. This movement affected large parts of Europe, North America, and Africa, and resulted in the formation of the Appalachian Mountains in North America, the Massif Central in France, and the Harz Mountains in Germany. The Hercynian movement was caused by the collision of the ancient continents of Gondwana and Laurussia, which resulted in the closure of the Rheic Ocean and the formation of the supercontinent Pangaea.
testCases.expectedOutput: It refers to the late Paleozoic orogeny. The Hercynian movement caused the Hercynian geosyncline in Western Europe, the Appalachian geosyncline in eastern North America, the Ural geosyncline at the Eurasian border, the Kazakh geosyncline in Central Asia, and the Tianshan, South Qinling and Great Khingan Mountains in China to fold back, forming a huge mountain system. At this time, the geosyncline zone between the ancient platforms in the northern hemisphere became denuded mountains, and the completion of Hercynian tectonic stage marked the end of the Paleozoic era.

Fossils are well preserved, and even some fine structures are preserved, indicating that it is a still water environment. The sediment is fine and has horizontal lamination, which also indicates that the water body is calm and the transportation distance is far. Generally, it should be the sediment from the deeper part of the shallow lake area to the deep lake area (the center of the lake) under the humid climate.

testCases.name: test_case_186
testCases.input: Purplish red siltstone or silty mudstone with halite pseudolite
testCases.actualOutput: Pseudolite is a term used in geoscience to describe a rock that has a similar appearance to another rock type, but is actually composed of a different mineral. In this case, the rock is a purplish red siltstone or silty mudstone with halite pseudolite, meaning that it appears to be a halite rock, but is actually composed of siltstone or silty mudstone.
testCases.expectedOutput: The rock is purplish red and red, composed of silty sand or clay, and cubic rock salt pseudolite can be seen on the layer. The formation of halite is closely related to the arid climate. Under dry climate conditions, due to massive evaporation of water and increasing salinity in the water body, rock salt crystallizes when the salinity reaches saturation. Most of the halite pseudocrystals seen in the rocks are isolated and scattered crystals. It is speculated that the halite was not dried up in the whole basin when it was formed, but only occurred in some shallow water sections. The rock salt crystals are covered by sediments after growing, and dissolved due to the reduction of salinity of seawater. The remaining voids are filled with clay components, thus preserving the crystal form of rock salt, so it is called rock salt pseudo-crystal. The rocks are mainly fine-grained sediments, indicating that the terrain was flat at that time, representing the deposition of coastal or lakeside areas under dry climate conditions. The environment is usually judged according to the fossils contained in this set of rocks and its upper and lower strata. If there are marine fossils, it may be coastal sediments. If there are terrestrial lacustrine biological assemblages, it should be coastal sediments.

testCases.name: test_case_187
testCases.actualOutput: Oolitic hematite is a mineral that is a form of iron oxide (Fe2O3) and is characterized by its spherical, concentrically layered structure. It is formed by the precipitation of iron oxide around a nucleus, such as a sand grain or a shell fragment, in a shallow marine environment. Oolitic hematite is typically reddish-brown in color and has a hardness of 5.5 to 6 on the Mohs scale. It is often found in sedimentary rocks, such as sandstones and conglomerates, and is used as a pigment in paints and coatings.
testCases.expectedOutput: The rock is iron red, the basic composition is hematite (Fe2O3), with oolitic structure, and the diameter of oolite is about 0.5~2mm, sometimes containing biofossil fragments. Oolitic hematite represents that under warm and humid climate conditions, iron can exist in acidic water as a colloid (the water body contains humic acid and is acidic), and then be brought to the beach and shallow sea by the river. Under the condition of water turbulence, the iron can be condensed and precipitated with gravel or bone chips as the core. It is speculated that it represents the turbulent shallow sea high-energy environment under humid, hot and humid climate conditions.

The laminae can vary in thickness, ranging from a few millimeters to several centimeters, and can be composed of different materials, such as minerals, organic matter, or fossils. Laminated structures are commonly found in sedimentary rocks, such as shale, siltstone, and sandstone, and can provide valuable information about the depositional environment and the history of the rock formation.

Its growth forms two basic laminae due to seasonal changes: the first is algae-rich laminae, also known as dark layer or dark zone, which is dark because of the high content of algae components and rich in organic matter; The other is rich in carbonate laminae, with less algae content and less organic matter, so the color is light. Two basic laminations appear alternately, forming a laminated structure. P2072

testCases.name: test_case_226
testCases.actualOutput: Magmatic rock is a type of rock that is formed from the cooling and solidification of magma or lava. It is characterized by its crystalline structure and can be classified into three main types: intrusive, extrusive, and pyroclastic. Intrusive magmatic rocks are formed when magma cools and solidifies beneath the Earth's surface, while extrusive magmatic rocks are formed when lava cools and solidifies on the Earth's surface. Pyroclastic magmatic rocks are formed from volcanic eruptions and are composed of fragments of solidified lava, ash, and other volcanic materials. The composition of magmatic rocks can vary widely, depending on the chemical composition of the magma or lava from which they are formed.
testCases.expectedOutput: It refers to the shape and scale of magmatic rock mass in space, the relationship between magmatic rock mass and surrounding rock, and the depth and geological tectonic environment at the time of formation.

testCases.name: test_case_234
testCases.input: Clear water sedimentation of carbonate rocks
testCases.actualOutput: Clear water sedimentation of carbonate rocks refers to the process of sedimentation of carbonate rocks in clear water environments. This process involves the accumulation of carbonate sediments, such as calcite and aragonite, in areas with low levels of suspended particles and high levels of light penetration. The sedimentation process is driven by the settling of carbonate particles from the water column, which can occur due to gravity, biological activity, or chemical reactions. Clear water sedimentation of carbonate rocks is important for the formation of carbonate platforms, reefs, and other carbonate structures, which are important habitats for marine life and provide valuable resources for human use.
testCases.expectedOutput: It refers to the carbonate deposition in the epicontinental sea environment where there is no or little inflow of terrigenous materials.

testCases.actualOutput: Clear water sedimentation of carbonate rocks refers to the process of sedimentation of carbonate rocks in clear water environments. This process involves the accumulation of carbonate sediments, such as calcite and aragonite, in areas with low levels of suspended particles and high levels of light penetration. The sedimentation process is driven by the settling of carbonate particles from the water column, which can occur due to gravity, biological activity, or chemical reactions. Clear water sedimentation of carbonate rocks is important for the formation of carbonate platforms, reefs, and other carbonate structures, which are important habitats for marine life and provide valuable resources for human use.

testCases.name: test_case_305
testCases.actualOutput: Magmatic rock is a type of rock that is formed from the cooling and solidification of magma or lava. It is characterized by its crystalline structure and can be classified into three main types: intrusive, extrusive, and pyroclastic. Intrusive magmatic rocks are formed when magma cools and solidifies beneath the Earth's surface, while extrusive magmatic rocks are formed when lava cools and solidifies on the Earth's surface. Pyroclastic magmatic rocks are formed from volcanic eruptions and are composed of fragments of solidified lava, ash, and other volcanic materials. The composition of magmatic rocks can vary widely, depending on the chemical composition of the magma or lava from which they are formed.
testCases.expectedOutput: It refers to the shape and scale of magmatic rock mass in space, the relationship between magmatic rock mass and surrounding rock, and the depth and geological tectonic environment at the time of formation.

testCases.name: test_case_263

It is characterized by its crystalline structure and can be classified into three main types: intrusive, extrusive, and pyroclastic. Intrusive magmatic rocks are formed when magma cools and solidifies beneath the Earth's surface, while extrusive magmatic rocks are formed when lava cools and solidifies on the Earth's surface. Pyroclastic magmatic rocks are formed from volcanic eruptions and are composed of fragments of solidified lava, ash, and other volcanic materials. The composition of magmatic rocks can vary widely, depending on the chemical composition of the magma or lava from which they are formed.

testCases.name: test_case_307
testCases.actualOutput: Magmatic differentiation is the process by which a single magma can produce a variety of different igneous rocks with different mineral compositions. This occurs as the magma cools and crystallizes, with different minerals forming at different temperatures. As the magma cools, the minerals that crystallize first will be removed from the remaining magma, causing the composition of the remaining magma to change. This process can result in the formation of a wide range of igneous rocks, from mafic rocks such as basalt to felsic rocks such as granite.
testCases.expectedOutput: It refers to the whole process of the original homogeneous magma, without the addition of foreign materials, finally producing magma of different composition by its own evolution.

testCases.name: test_case_340
testCases.actualOutput: A mid-ocean ridge is a mountain range that runs along the ocean floor. It is formed by the upwelling of magma from the mantle, which creates new oceanic crust as it cools and solidifies. The ridge is characterized by a central rift valley, which is a deep, narrow depression that runs along the ridge's crest. Mid-ocean ridges are the longest mountain ranges on Earth, stretching for over 65,000 kilometers (40,000 miles) across the globe. They are also the sites of frequent volcanic activity and earthquakes, as the tectonic plates that make up the ocean floor are constantly moving and interacting with one another.
testCases.expectedOutput: The global ocean floor mountain system across the ocean is called the mid-ocean ridge. It is the zone where the oceanic crust is generated, and its seismic and volcanic activities are very strong. There is a huge rift in the central part of the mid-ocean ridge called the central rift.

testCases.name: test_case_337
testCases.actualOutput: The continental shelf is the submerged part of a continent that extends from the shoreline to the continental slope. It is typically characterized by a gentle slope and a relatively shallow depth, with an average depth of about 100 meters. The continental shelf is an important area for marine life and is often rich in resources such as oil and gas.
testCases.expectedOutput: It refers to the shallow submarine valley surrounding the mainland, with flat terrain and an average slope of more than 0.3 degrees (the shallow platform surrounding the mainland has an average slope of 0 degrees and 7 minutes, with an average width of about 75 kilometers, a depth of about 60 meters, and a lower boundary depth of about 130 meters). Island arc: arc-shaped islands that extend far and are distributed in bands. The island arc protrudes to the ocean, and the inner side is the continent. Trench: a narrow and long depression with a depth of more than 6000 meters is often developed outside the island arc. It is about a few to dozens of kilometers wide. The island arc and trench form an arc - trench system, which is often developed at the boundary of land and ocean. Ocean basin: the main body of the seabed, which is a relatively flat zone between the continental margin and the mid-ocean ridge, with a general water depth of 4000-6000 meters. Deep-sea plain: a gentle zone near the continental margin with an average depth of about 4877 meters and a very small slope (<1/1000).

testCases.name: test_case_347
testCases.actualOutput: The Gutenberg discontinuity is the boundary between the Earth's mantle and outer core. It is located at a depth of approximately 2,900 kilometers (1,800 miles) below the Earth's surface. The discontinuity is characterized by a sudden change in seismic wave velocities, with P-waves (primary waves) slowing down and S-waves (secondary waves) disappearing altogether. This is due to the transition from the solid mantle to the liquid outer core. The Gutenberg discontinuity is named after the German seismologist Beno Gutenberg, who first identified it in the 1910s.
testCases.expectedOutput: At 2891KM, the seismic wave is about 3000KM underground, and the discontinuity with continuous and violent changes in propagation is located at the interface between the lower mantle and the outer core.

testCases.name: test_case_428

testCases.actualOutput: In college geoscience, grade refers to the slope of a surface, expressed as a percentage or as an angle in degrees. Grade is an important concept in geoscience as it affects the movement of water, soil, and other materials on the Earth's surface.
